Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
Project Number: 54391-003 
Transaction Technical Assistance Cluster (C-TRTA) 
February 2021 
 
 
Technical Assistance for Gender Mainstreaming and 
Gender Initiatives in Nonsovereign Operations 
 
Subproject 2: Technical Assistance for WAVES 
Program’s Private Sector Development in Pacific 
Countries  
(Regional)  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to Information 
Policy.

ABBREVIATIONS

Asia and the Pacific Program

CONTENTS 
Page 
 
I.  THE WAVES PROGRAM IN PACIFIC COUNTRIES  1 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE SUBPROJECTS  2 
A.  Overall Progress of the Technical Assistance Cluster  2 
B.  Subprojects Scope  2 
C.  Subproject Outputs and Activities  2 
D.  Cost and Indicative Financing  5

APPENDIXES 
1.  List of Linked Documents  7

I.  THE WAVES PROGRAM IN PACIFIC COUNTRIES  
 
1.  The Cluster Technical Assistance for Gender Mainstreaming and Gender Initiatives in 
Nonsovereign Operations, approved in November 2020, aims to provide capacity building support 
to PSOD programs and projects with adequate resources to develop capacities and knowledge 
in response to the greater attention given by international development partners and finance 
institutions, including ADB, to a more systematic inclusion of measures supporting gender equality 
and women’s empowerment as part of private sector development projects. As such, the technical 
assistance (TA) cluster proposes to host under the same umbrella different PSOD initiatives to 
support gender mainstreaming, including supporting access to finance for women-owned small 
and medium-sized enterprises (WSMEs) in the Pacific under the Women Accelerating Vibrant 
Enterprises in Southeast Asia and the Pacific Program (WAVES) with the resources obtained 
from the Women Entrepreneurs Finance Initiative (We-Fi).1  
 
2.  The Pacific component of the WAVES program was designed to unlock the growth 
potential of WSMEs, overcoming gender-specific constraints in the Pacific by building capacity 
across the entrepreneurial eco-system, in partnership with governments, the private sector, 
including financial institutions (FIs) and women’s businesses, to open new doors and create an 
empowering environment for WSMEs to grow and scale up. For that purpose, ADB obtained funds 
from We-Fi in April 2019 to support access to finance for WSMEs through FIs in the two largest 
economies of the region, Fiji and Papua New Guinea (PNG). The We-Fi governing committee 
approved a comprehensive program that included four activities that are summarized under the 
proposed Technical Assistance for WAVES Program’s Private Sector Development in Pacific 
Countries, as Subproject 2 of the Cluster Technical Assistance for Gender Mainstreaming and 
Gender Initiatives in Nonsovereign Operations.  
 
3.  Constraints faced by WSMEs growing their businesses and accessing financing have 
been largely documented: a combination of gender-biased norms (e.g. misperceptions/ bias of 
loan officers), and lack of access to opportunities due to prevailing gender inequalities, such as 
unpaid  care  responsibilities,  gender-based  violence,  and  discrimination  against  female 
participation. This results in lower levels of financial and digital literacy, limited opportunities for 
networking, mentorship, training, and therefore, more difficulties in accessing financing.2 These 
constraints are further exacerbated in times of economic downturns or external shocks such as 
the one provoked by the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic. FIs also face difficulties, serving 
WSMEs with traditional lending practices such as non-differentiated approaches which are heavily 
reliant on traditional collateral requirements of land and tangible assets, the majority of which is 
not owned by women.  
 
4.  In the Pacific, governments have enacted a series of policy and regulatory reforms to 
support business development, which have had some direct positive spillovers for women. 
Through ADB’s Private Sector Development Initiative (PSDI), governments across the region 
have introduced secured transactions laws (Fiji, PNG, Vanuatu, Tonga, Solomon Islands), online 
business registries (Samoa, Solomon Islands, Tonga, Vanuatu), and developed policies on 
public-private partnerships (PNG, Fiji, Tonga). In Fiji, the Fiji Development Bank and the National 
Centre for Small and Micro Enterprise Development top-up loans to small businesses (up to $500) 
 
1  The Women Entrepreneurs Finance Initiative is a groundbreaking partnership that aims to unlock financing for 
women-led and women-owned businesses in developing countries. We-Fi’s partners include 14 donor governments, 
six multilateral development banks as implementing partners, and numerous other stakeholders in the public and 
private sector around the world. 
2  ADB/AusAid/New  Zealand  Aid  Program.  Pacific  Private  Sector  Development  Initiative. 
http://www.adbpsdi.org/p/what-is-psdi.html

2   
provided that at least 40% of the loan is obtained from other financial institutions. However, 
programs targeting women’s businesses have tended to focus on microenterprise support such 
as that offered by the Fiji Ministry of Women, Children and Poverty Alleviation, which provides 
grants of up to $2,500 to individuals or groups of women working collectively to start up small 
informal businesses.  
 
5.  The WAVES Pacific program seeks to address the above-mentioned constraints by:  
i) supporting the structuring of an innovative blended finance product; ii) strengthening the 
capacity of partner financial institutions; iii) supporting the development of gender-responsive 
digital finance solutions in partnership with local financial institutions; and iv) developing the 
capacity of WSMEs. These are the four subcomponents that were originally approved by We-Fi. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE SUBPROJECTS 
 
A.  Overall Progress of the Technical Assistance Cluster 
 
6.  This TA subproject follows the recent approval of the TA for Gender Mainstreaming and 
Gender Initiatives in Nonsovereign Operations Cluster report (TA Cluster), which is  comprised of 
five subprojects that focus on: (i) supporting private sector projects categorized Effective Gender 
Mainstreaming  or  Gender  Equity  Theme  under  the  ADB’s  categorization  system  in  the 
implementation of their gender action plans; (ii) increasing women’s access to finance in the 
Pacific  for  women  businesses  through  the  WAVES  Program;  (iii)  enhancing  gender 
mainstreaming in climate finance projects under the Australian Climate Financing Partnership;  
(iv) developing knowledge and tools to promote gender-lens financing by financial institutions; 
and (v) enhancing gender mainstreaming in venture capital financing operations. The TA Cluster 
specifies that the subprojects are not mutually dependent and may be presented and approved 
in any order. Not all of these five subprojects may materialize and/or additional subprojects may 
be developed over the course of the TA Cluster.  
 
B.  Subprojects Scope 
 
7.  The WAVES Pacific program includes four activities as originally approved by We-Fi. 
These  include:  i)  supporting  the  structuring  of  an  innovative  blended  finance  product;  
ii) strengthening the capacity of partner financial institutions; iii) supporting the development of 
gender-responsive digital finance solutions in partnership with local financial institutions; and  
iv) developing the capacity of WSMEs. 
 
C.  Subproject Outputs and Activities  
 
1.  Output 1: Improved capacities of ADB private sector clients to develop and 
implement gender mainstreaming initiatives and gender action plans  
 
1.1. Activity 1: Structuring of an innovative blended finance product supported  
 
8.  Given the structural constraints faced by WSMEs to access finance in Pacific countries, 
blended finance is needed to provide the necessary incentives for FIs to lend to WSMEs, as well 
as for WSMEs to overcome some of the challenges, such as lack of access to capital. This activity 
will aim to support increasing access to finance for WSMEs by structuring an innovative blended

3 
finance product in partnership with one or several FIs.3 Such product could be in the form of a 
gender bond, direct capital to specific FIs committed to increasing their portfolio of WSMEs, a 
patient capital equity-grant fund to support capital for WSMEs, a credit guarantee fund to cover 
the credit risks of WSMEs, or other similar products.  
 
9.  This  activity  will  finance  all  aspects  related  to  ADB’s  cost  for  the  structuring  and 
management of the innovative blended finance product, including but not limited to consultants, 
fund managers fees, legal fees, potential rating fees, social audits, marketing materials, and in 
the case of the gender bond, potential registration in the local stock exchange, potential credit 
rating of the bond, social audit, and other required activities. ADB will seek a project contribution 
from project counterparts as much as possible.  
 
10.  As a first step, a market study will be undertaken to assess the state of the women’s 
entrepreneurship sector and the enabling environment (both private and public) supporting 
WSMEs in order to determine the best-suited blended finance product. The study will aim to 
identify the characteristics of WSMEs and the current constraints faced by banks to serve this 
segment as a means to design a strategy to effectively serve this segment either through FIs 
supported by blended finance products or an alternative instrument such as a patient capital 
equity-grant fund, or a combination of both.  
 
1.2. Activity 2: capacity of partner financial institutions strengthened  
   
11.  To  effectively  serve  the  WSME  segment,  FIs  need  to  understand  the  specific 
characteristics and needs of WSMEs. Research indicates that men and women are likely to have 
different spending and saving priorities, different (foreseen and unforeseen) cash-flow needs at 
certain points in their personal lives and professional life-cycles, and different attitudes towards 
risk and growth. Further, when linked to the sector in which WSMEs operate (for example, trade 
versus agriculture), the needs may differ.  
 
12.  This activity will strengthen the FIs’ ability to serve WSMEs and develop the specific 
skillset and processes needed to assist this target segment. FIs will receive support to build their 
internal capacity to originate and service WSME loans, such as, conducting baseline gender gap 
analyses, preparing gender action plans, and supporting its implementation. It can also provide 
assistance in the development of gender-responsive products, likely in combination with activity 
3 described below. In the case of a gender bond issuance, the issuer FI will also receive capacity 
to comply with the Social Bonds Principles (SBP) (Voluntary Process Guidelines for Issuing Social 
Bonds) by the International Capital Market Association (ICMA).4 
 
1.3. Activity 3: gender-responsive digital finance solutions supported 
 
13.  The lack of infrastructure in Pacific countries, especially those with remote rural areas 
such as PNG, makes digital finance a relevant solution for increasing access to finance for 
WSMEs. This component will build on ADB’s experience of supporting the Bank of PNG in the 
creation of a national digital ID and the partnership that ADB has established with a local 
implementing partner, as well as ADB’s sovereign programs targeting the development of WSMEs. 
 
3  FIs will be selected according to specific criteria, such as (i) track-record, willingness and management buy-in to 
further improve their financing to WSMEs, (ii) implementation and execution capacity, (iii) need for blended finance 
in compliance with the blended finance principles. 
4 International  Capital  Market  Association.  Social  Bond  Principles.  https://www.icmagroup.org/green-social-and-
sustainability-bonds/social-bond-principles-sbp/.

4   
The WAVES funds will be used to implement some of the digital finance solutions that have 
already been identified with an emphasis on the needs of WSMEs.  
 
14.  Many FIs and women’s businesses in ADB’s developing member countries have not yet 
digitized their service delivery models. The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the need to face 
the challenge of digital transformation and ADB will seek to support FIs and WSMEs in addressing 
this opportunity.5 FIs will be identified and selected based on specific criteria, among others their 
need for digitization of business processes, their focus on increasing finance to WSMEs, and their 
management’s buy-in for the digital transformation. In the first phase, one such activity, as 
provided under this subproject, will be to conduct a market scoping and needs assessment for 
innovative financial technologies relevant for FIs that intend to increase their gender-responsive 
finance portfolio. These would be specific technologies that facilitate greater access to finance for 
women or women’s businesses. This can be done in cooperation with one FI or several FIs in a 
specific country or region, or on a stand-alone basis. Based on the assessment, an FI can be 
supported through ADB’s technology platform to identify suitable cutting-edge digital solutions for 
“last mile” service delivery targeting WSMEs with the potential to pilot such solutions.6 Such efforts 
would address issues such as a lack of infrastructure and connectivity, challenges of remote 
locations, efficiency and cost factors and gender disparities.  
 
15.  In addition, support can also be provided directly to an FI through information technology 
assessments as well as capacity building for specific gender lens financing topics and digital 
solutions such as alternative credit scoring models that incorporate gender specific data.7 This 
could be in the form of digitizing credit scoring models or integrating gender-specific data in the 
algorithms. Monitoring of the FI and evaluating the results from this work will also be a necessary 
part of the process to assess the impact of these initiatives.8 
 
2.  Output 2: Enhanced business and other skills of women-owned small and 
medium-sized enterprises 
 
16.  Emerging evidence from COVID-19 suggests that in lower- and low-income countries, lost 
income will result in an increase in relative poverty for informal workers and their families and that 
compared to men’s lives, women’s economic and productive lives are disproportionately and 
differently affected.9 The hardest hit sectors include retail trade and service industries, such as 
street vending and domestic work- typically low-wage jobs that rely on in-person connections and 
often carried out by women.10 A survey on the impact of COVID-19 on women’s businesses in 
PNG has found that 40.9% of smaller or semi-formal businesses have reported a temporary halt 
in operations.11 
 
 
5  First, focus will be on supporting FIs which are already ADB clients or potential new clients and have contacted ADB 
for support. The next phase will cover individual women’s businesses as well. 
6  This will be done in cooperation with ADB’s Information Technology Department. See challenges.adb.org or 
digital.adb.org. 
7  In cooperation with the FI, it can be decided whether ADB’s support comes in the form of consulting services, support 
through hackathon or sandbox programs or contribution to the FI’s own assessment, preparation, and implementation 
of new technologies. Cost matching from the FI will be sought as much as possible. 
8  It is envisaged that activities will be coordinated with REG TRTA: Technical Assistance for The Women’s Financing 
Marketplace, subproject 2: Innovation and Technology. 
9  UN Women 2020, Policy Brief: The Impact of COVID-19 on Women, 9 April 2020. 
10  Women in Informal Employment: Globalizing and Organizing (WIEGO), #3 Social Protection Responses to COVID-
19, 2020. 
11  CIBE 2020. COVID-19’s Arrival in PNG: Impacts on women-owned and -operated MSMEs. July 2020. Port Moresby

5 
17.  While access to finance to adapt business models to the “new normal” environment and 
operate more digitally is one challenge (such as e.g. using mobile payment channels, advertising 
through Facebook, selling through e-commerce platforms) that needs to be addressed, another 
challenge is that often WSMEs lack financial literacy and the skills and capacities to present 
bankable projects. The TA funds earmarked for PNG under this subproject will support WSMEs 
in PNG identified in partnership with FIs, through various means, and conduct tailormade training 
and coaching sessions for WSMEs in digital financial literacy, business planning, and debt 
management and other areas, as needed, to sustainably develop their businesses. A suitable 
training provider will be selected, and existing training curriculum and material will be adjusted to 
meet the needs of the WSMEs and the new online format. Providing training and coaching 
sessions online in the current environment will reach a wider audience and can be screened 
across multiple countries and regions. It is expected that some on-site coaching will remain, once 
the COVID-19 situation has improved. Further feedback from FIs on requirements for lending will 
also be incorporated.12 
 
18.  WSMEs will also be connected through networks (e.g. PNG Business Coalition of Women, 
Business  Advocacy  Network  or  Centre  for  International  Private  Enterprise)  and  potential 
accelerators that support WSMEs through tailor-made support and market access possibilities, 
as well as through enhanced sharing. Women’s business initiatives in PNG are quite strong and 
will be excellent partners for the development of training and coaching, as well as supporting 
networking  activities.  Networking  for  WSMEs  and  FIs  can  also  be  expanded  through  the 
Marketplace.13 
 
D.  Cost and Indicative Financing 
 
19.  The TA subproject is estimated to cost $1,250,000 of which all will be financed on a grant 
basis by We-Fi under the WAVES Program in accordance with the trust fund regulations.14  
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
20.  The TA will run until December 2024 in line with the approved implementation period of 
the WAVES Program. ADB will administer the TA and its Private Sector Operations Department’s, 
Financial Institutions Division will implement it in consultation with PSOD Gender Team and 
SDCC to recruit specific consultant services for each output activity and reporting to We-Fi. 
Disbursements under this TA will be made in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Handbook (2020, as amended from time to time).  
 
21.  Consulting services. Individual consultants (national/international) will be recruited by 
PSOD/PSFI in accordance with the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to 
time) and the associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions. A firm may 
also be recruited using the quality and cost-based selection method. A single-source selection 
may also be considered, subject to required approvals, should specific expertise be required. 
Shopping procedures may be used as appropriate for non-consulting services. The estimated 
cost and requisite fields of expertise15 are indicative, and estimates will be finalized prior to 
advertisement. 16 Output based and/or lump-sum contracts will be considered but time-based 
 
12  It is envisaged that the training and coaching is coordinated with activities under REG TRTA: Technical Assistance 
for Women’s Financing Marketplace, subproject 3: Capacity Building.  
13  REG C-TRTA 0050 Technical Assistance for the Women's Financing Marketplace. 
14 An implied waiver for cost recovery is deemed received. 
15  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
16  As applicable, fixed out-of-pocket expenses, for administrative efficiency and to simplify the disbursement process 
will be used.

6   
contracts will be used, as appropriate. Advance contracting will be considered to for early 
recruitment purposes. No contracts will be signed with consultants until subprojects have been 
approved. 
 
22.  Asset turnover or disposal arrangement upon TA completion. If goods are procured 
by ADB, ADB may turn them over to the recipient or TASU will follow the disposal procedure 
indicated in AO 4.02 in consultation with OAS. 
 
23.  Co-Financier Requirements. This TA subproject of the C-TRTA Technical Assistance 
for Gender Mainstreaming and Gender Initiatives in Nonsovereign Operations will be entirely 
financed by We-Fi. As such, eligibility, implementation, monitoring and reporting of activities will 
be carried out in accordance with the Financial Procedures Agreement signed between ADB and 
the International Bank of Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) as the We-Fi trustee in 
January 2018.

7
